 I. BACKGROUND A. BANK INVOLVEMENT IN ENERGY 1. The Bank has been heavily involved in the energy sector in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the past, notably in electric power, petroleum and natural gas. In the gas sector, the Bank financed the Naftagas Pipeline Project (Loan 916-YU; US$59.4 million; 1973) and the Sarajevo Air Pollution Control Project (Loan 1264-YU; US$38 million; 1975). Power sector projects, which benefited BH partly or exclusively, included: the Third Power Project (Loan 386-YU; US$75 million; 1972) and the Fourth Power Project (Loan 1469-YU; US$80 million; 1977), both of which helped finance the development of SFRY's interconnected power system; the Fifth Power Project (Loan 1561-YU; US$73 million; 1978), which was for the development of the hydro power plants on the middle Neretva River; the Sixth Power Project (Loan 1561-1-YU; US$61 million; 1983), which was for construction of the Mostar dam; the Seventh Power Project (Loan 2338-YU; US$120 million; 1984), which financed SFRY's energy management system; and the Eighth Power Project, which was for the Visegrad hydropower plant (Loan 2527-YU; US$125 million; 1985). In the petroleum sector, the Bank financed the First Petroleum Project (Loan 2597-YU; US$92.5 million; 1985) for the development of indigenous energy resources. Since the Bank resumed lending to Bosnia in 1996, a US$20 million Trust Fund credit was approved on May 14, 1996 for an Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project (TF 024034) and a US$35 million IDA credit for an Emergency Electric Power Reconstruction Project with a coal mining component was approved on July 31, 1996 (Credit 2903-BOS). B. ELECTRIC POWER 2. Background. In 1990, BH produced 13,090 Gigawatt hours (GWh) of electricity from generating plants located on its territory. Electricity consumption was 11,181 GWh. The system comprised 13 hydropower plants with a total capacity of 2,034 Megawatts (MW) and an average output of 6,922 GWh/year (2,415 GWh in 1990), and 12 thermal power plants with a total capacity of 1,957 Megawatts (MW) and an output of 10,675 GWh in 1990. The thermal power plants were brown coal and lignite fired, with the fuel coming from mines within BH. BH was responsible for operating its own system and meeting local demand. However, being part of the former Yugoslav network, the 400 kV power grid in BH was controlled by JUGEL's dispatching center in Belgrade. Power exchanges with neighboring countries were also controlled by JUGEL. 3. As of January 1, 1996, 58% of total generating capacity in the Federation area (comparable data are not available for Republika Srpska) was reported to have been damaged. Part of the remaining capacity is out of operation due to destroyed transmission lines or lack of coal. About 60% of the transmission network and control system was seriously damaged, including transmission facilities and interconnection lines to neighboring countries. The distribution network was largely destroyed. Many transformer stations, buildings, telecommunications and maintenance equipment were also either seriously damaged or destroyed.
 2 4. Sector Strategy. The proposed sector strategy would be to: (i) restore service to acceptable levels; (ii) reconfigure the electric power network to optimize the system, taking into account BH's need for significant independence from the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia's (FRY) network and its security of supply; (iii) restructure the sector and introduce a regulatory framework that would facilitate attracting potential investors; and (iv) improve sector finances by improving billing and collections and revising the tariff structure and levels to reflect supply costs for each category of consumers. An Emergency Electric Power Reconstruction Project was approved by the Board of Directors on July 31, 1996. C. COAL 5. Background. In the 1980's, the coal mines in BH produced annually about 18 million tons, of which 10 million tons of brown coal and 8 million tons of lignite. Their brown coal output accounted for about 80% of total former SFRY production, lignite for only 15%. Production was concentrated in areas near Tuzla and Zenica in both open pit as well as underground mines. In addition, two rnines in the Republika Srpska were important: Ugljevik: (brown coal) and Gacko (lignite). About half of the production originated from surface mines and the other half from underground mines. BH's proven reserves of coal are about 1.6 billion tons. More than 80% of BH's total production was used for electric power generation and the remaining 20% for industrial and household uses. 6. Coal production dropped to 1.5 million tons in 1994, i.e., less than 10% of the pre-war level. Much of the mobile mining equipment has been cannibalized beyond repair. Some newer mobile equipment had to be turned over to the army or just disappeared. There is an acute lack of critical materials such as fuel, tires and spare parts. Yet, despite the drastic drop in production, no efforts were made to concentrate production in a few large and economic mines. The number of people employed decreased from 26,000 to about 7,000. Since production declined much faster, productivity is now among the lowest in the world. Present production costs appear to be at or above the world market level of coal prices adjusted for quality and are higher than sales prices, which are set by the State. To ensure future financial viability, coal mining enterprises need to close uneconomic capacity. 7. Sector Strategy. In view of the coal sector's uncertain future in a market economy, all major long-term investment decisions should be avoided at this stage. The sector strategy is to: (i) determine priority actions to be taken for the lowest cost and most competitive mines necessary to provide fuel to cogenerating plants and other priority users; (ii) restore output of the lowest-cost mines to minimum acceptable levels; and (iii) restructure the coal industry, including closing uneconomic mining capacity and privatizing services wherever feasible. D. DISTRcT HEATING 8. Background. In 1991, BH had district heating (DH) systems in most major towns and cities with a population in excess of about 25,000 inhabitants. The systems were generally run by
 3 municipally-owned district heating enterprises (DHEs). Cogenerated heat was provided only by the combined heat and power plants in Tuzla and Kakanj as well as by local industries; the remaining heat was generated by local heat-only boilers. Prior to the war, some efforts had been made to start converting coal-fired boilers to gas or oil firing, notably in Sarajevo. DH systems throughout BH served 120,000 flats, equivalent to 450,000 inhabitants or 10% of the total population. The Sarajevo DH system was the country's largest, serving about 180,000 inhabitants or 45% of the pre-war population of Sarajevo. 9. Currently, the DH systems in major cities such as Sarajevo, Banja Luka, Bihac and Mostar are only partly operational. In Sarajevo, the system has been damaged due to shelling and freezing of the pipes in the network; building internals in residential dwellings (pipes, radiators and valves) have incurred substantial damage, also due to the corrosion associated with non-usage of the system. In cities such as Banja Luka, most of the damage is related to non-usage of the system due to lack of fuel, and associated rusting and freezing. In all cities, lack of maintenance due to the absence of spare parts has been significant and further aggravated the problems. 10. Sector Strategy. The sector strategy is to: (i) restore urban district heating services to adequate levels as soon as possible, disconnect serviced flats from the gas system (in Sarajevo) and reduce fuel wood consumption (in other cities); (ii) rehabilitate building internal heating installations; (iii) strengthen sector institutions and increase cost recovery; and (iv) undertake master plan studies to prepare plans for the optimal configuration of each city's future heating system. An Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project was approved by the Board of Directors on May 14, 1996 (TF 024034); implementation is fully satisfactory. E. NATURAL GAS 11. Background. The gas system in BH was developed starting in 1975 under the Bank's Sarajevo Air Pollution Control Project (Loan 1264-YU; US$38 million). Russian gas is supplied via Hungary and Serbia and enters BH at Zvornik, in Republika Srpska. As of 1992 the gas supply network consisted of 182 km of transmission mains and offiake pipes, running from Zvornik to the Sarajevo area via Semizovac and from the latter to Zenica. Consumption peaked in 1990 with 610 million cubic meters, constituting 8% of the total energy consumption in BH. Within Sarajevo, there were 15,000 household connections and all major boilers of the city's district heating network had been converted from coal to gas-firing. Gas imports for BH are metered at the Ukraine/Hungarian border (Beregov, the contractual point of delivery of the gas) and from there it is transported through the Hungarian and FRY transmission systems to Zvornik. The gas was imported under a contract between Energopetrol, a state-owned oil and gas company, and Gazexport, the export branch of Russia's Gazprom. Within BH, gas transmission and distribution was the responsibility of Sarajevogas (para. 27). 12. At the beginning of the war, use of gas upstream reduced the supply coming into Sarajevo to such an extent that gas use for industry and much of the district heating system became impossible. Because of the destruction of part of the district heating system in Sarajevo early on and a sharp reduction in electricity supply, gas suddenly assumed major importance for the inhabitants of Sarajevo as a means to stay warm and to cook. Many improvised connections and
 4 appliances were made which, combined with an absence of odorization, often led to explosions and highly inefficient gas use. However, odorization equipment was reintroduced in December 1995 through humanitarian aid. As of the end of 1995, the total number of household connections in all of Sarajevo was estimated at around 89,000; gas consumption constituted about 70% of all energy consumption and it was the basic heating and cooking fuel for the city's remaining 300,000 inhabitants. 13. Debt to Gazexport. During the war, the gas supply from Semizovac to Zenica (the entire western branch of the transmission system, affecting several major industries along that line) was shut off. However, some gas was allowed to come into Sarajevo. In exchange, gas was allowed to go to FRY. The total bill for gas supplied to BH by Gazexport during the war was about US$105 million as of October 10, 1995. Settlement of the debt outstanding as of October 10, 1995 is expected to take place as part of the commercial debt negotiations. A new interim contract for the period October 10, 1995-December 31, 1996 signed between Gazexport and Energoinvest called for delivery of gas to both the Federation and the Republika Srpska combined. 14. Agreement was reached in January 1997 on a new three-year gas supply contract. However, Gazexport was insisting on prior payment of an unpaid balance of US$16.2 million under the October 1995 contract before the new contract could become effective. In fact, due to continuing payment problems the gas supply to BH was gradually reduced and finally cut off on April 1, 1997. Since the major issue was a dispute between the Federation and RS about their respective shares of the arrears, the Bank mounted a major effort to resolve these differences. As a result, the Federation and RS agreed to an arrears settlement scheme' as well as to the need to renegotiate the existing gas supply and transit agreements in order to have a separate agreement for each Entity. This would ensure that, in the event one of the two parties defaults on its payments to Gazexport or the transit companies (MOL of Hungary and Nis-Gas of Yugoslavia), the supply of gas to the other party could be maintained. The Federation settled all its arrears to Gazexport and the flow of gas to the Federation resumed on October 31, 1997. The resupply of gas to RS will take place once it has come to a satisfactory agreement with Gazexport on arrears repayment and payment for future consumption (the humanitarian need for gas in RS is far less critical than in Sarajevo: over 90% of the gas is consumed by an alumina factory and most inhabitants using gas have alternative means of heating). II. BANK RESPONSE AND STRATEGY 15. The conclusion of the Dayton-Paris Peace Agreement in December 1995 ended Europe's most destructive war of the last fifty years. It was the first step towards reconciliation and reconstruction for Bosnia and Herzegovina, a task whose outcome could make or break the peace process. Large numbers of refugees and displaced persons, severely damaged infrastructure IThe Federation agreed to pay US$7.3 million, of which the Dutch Trust Fund paid US$4.7 million, while RS agreed to pay US8.9 million. Efforts are underway to obtain donor financing to help RS settle its arrears with Gazexport.
 - ~~5 facilities, and lack of a unified economic management structure make for an unparalleled challenge for post-war reconstruction. 16. Loss in human resources and damages. At least 200-250,000 people are dead or missing, and over 1 million people left the country. In addition, there are about 1.5 million displaced people in the country, many of whom live in temporary shelters. Enormous damage has been inflicted on the country's physical infrastructure, including energy. Direct war damages are huge, probably in the range of US$15-20 billion. Indirect damage due to lack of maintenance and corrosion accounts for many more billions of dollars of losses. 17. Institutional Framework. Under the Dayton-Paris Agreement, Bosnia and Herzegovina is an internationally recognized country consisting of two entities: the Bosniac-Croat Federation (Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina) and the Republika Srpska. There is a State Government responsible for foreign affairs, customs and foreign trade policies, monetary management, and inter-entity matters on communication, transport. All other responsibilities including defense, energy, social services and social welfare, have been devolved to the Federation and the Republika Srpska separately. 18. Macroeconomic Setting. Since the signing of the Peace Agreement, Bosnia and Herzegovina has experienced the beginnings of political, economic and social recovery. While living standards are still very low for many Bosnian families and economic activity is only at about one-third of prewar levels, the reconstruction effort has already borne significant fruit. Economic growth in 1996 reached 50 percent. Unemployment has declined from its postwar high of 90 percent to well below 50 percent. Many schools and health clinics have reopened, repairs to infrastructure are well underway. Commerce and production are picking up with the help of donor-financed lines of credit. The effects of reconstruction and growth are particularly evident in the Bosniac/Croat Federation where much of the international aid has been directed. Recovery in Republika Srpska began only after international sanctions were lifted in March 1996, and has been proceeding at a slower pace than in the Federation. A. BANK/IDA ASSISTANCE STRATEGY 19. On April 1, 1996, Bosnia and Herzegovina fulfilled the conditions of succession to the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia's membership in the Bank, IDA and IFC. Membership is retroactive to February 25, 1993. The resolution of Bosnia's arrears with the World Bank, through consolidation of its IBRD debt, allowed regular Bank lending to begin in June 1996. With a war-devastated economy, low post-war per capita GDP and lack of creditworthiness, Bosnia was declared IDA eligible. 20. Since early 1995, the Bank Group has been deeply involved in developing, with the BH authorities, a blueprint for reconstruction of the country's economy. A three- to four-year Priority Reconstruction Program totaling some $5.1 billion was presented to, and endorsed by a donors' conference co-sponsored by the Bank and the EU, following signing of the Dayton-Paris Peace Accords in December 1995. This conference, and a second one in April 1996, led to 1996 commitments of about US$1.8 billion from some sixty bilateral and multilateral donors for
 6 immediate and priority reconstruction activities. A third donors' conference held in July 1997 secured additional donor commitments of US$1.2 billion for 1997. 21. During 1996, the Bank followed an assistance strategy aimed at jump-starting economic activity through support of a broad range of economic sectors. Leveraging Bank resources with significant funding from donors was an important element of this strategy. Before arrears resolution, the Bank supported a series of immediate assistance programs through a special $150 million Trust Fund for Bosnia and Herzegovina (TFBH). Seven emergency operations were approved under the TFBH, including rebuilding of government institutions and funding of a line of credit to small business, as well as support for rehabilitation in the agriculture, water and sanitation, transport, health, education and district heating sectors. 22. Since the start of regular Bank lending in mid-1996, US$257.6 million in IDA resources have been committed, supporting an additional 13 operations focused on clearing of landmines, reconstruction of electric power, transport infrastructure, housing, hospitals and schools, establishment of a guarantee facility for industry, and three programs to support recovery of employment through public works, re-training and loans to microbusinesses. IDA's assistance program also supported the initial phase of the government's macroeconomic and institutional reforms: a Transition Assistance Credit, approved by the Board in September 1996, was the first operation focusing on institution-building in the Federation and a series of structural reforms needed for advancing the transition to a market-economy; and under the Second Transport Project, approved by the Board in August 1997, an adjustment component supports similar key structural reforms in the RS. The IFC has pending commitments of about US$10.7 million to various small and medium sized enterprise projects. 23. While emphasis during the first post-war year was on moving quickly with emergency reconstruction across a range of sectors, IDA's assistance strategy for fiscal years 1998 and 1999 shifts the focus to sustainability and ensuring the medium- to long- term viability of policies and investments. Significant donor resources are needed for the next several years; however, BH must increasingly become more self-reliant in preparation for the time when these inflows are no longer available. This will mean viable government institutions, sustainable government budgets, improved cost-recovery policies and mechanisms and structural reforms that stimulate private investment. Three overarching objectives will guide Bank Group strategy: (i) further development of the basic institutional infrastructure for economic management; (ii) transition to a market economy through deepening of major structural reforms; and (iii) continued, selective support of physical reconstruction. 24. Further policy-enhancing investment or adjustment operations are envisaged to support institution-building at the State and Entity level, as well as key reforms in the areas of public finance, banking, privatization and trade liberalization. In the area of reconstruction, future Bank operations will support key areas such as the network infrastructure sectors of energy and transport, as well as education, agriculture and other sectors essential to economic recovery. Limited IDA resources will continue to make partnerships with other donors essential: Mobilizing co-funding for future operations, and coordinating strategies -- e.g., eventual exit from those sectors where other donors are more fully engaged or have greater comparative advantage - - will be important elements of this partnership.
 7 25. Project Specific. The Bank delayed processing of the proposed Project because the supply of gas to Sarajevo remained tenuous and was, in fact, cut off by Gazexport starting on April 1, 1997. The Bank took the position that, as long as there was no sound long-term gas supply contract with credible payment mechanisms, it could not make major investments in the urgently needed reconfiguration and reconstruction of the Sarajevo gas distribution system and associated transmission facilities. Nevertheless, the Bank allowed Sarajevogas to withdraw about US$5 million against the Project's US$6 million Project Start-up Advance (para. 65) for urgent requirements, notably for purchasing regulators and meters necessary for the district heating system's boilers as well as for rehabilitating, procuring and installing household meters and regulator sets. 26. When it became clear that the gas supply to Bosnia would not be restored unless the Federation and RS would be separately responsible for their respective consumption, the Bank took an active role in convincing all parties, both within and without BH, that there should be separate contracts throughout the gas supply chain for the Federation and RS (para. 14). The Bank was also instrumental in brokering agreement on the operation and maintenance of the pipeline section within RS, with transit fees to be paid by Energoinvest to Energopetrol Pale. Commercial meters were installed on the main pipeline in Zvornik in February 1997 and Energoinvest will have free and unhindered access to these meters. Under the project, existing control meters in Kladanj will be replaced by commercial meters with greater accuracy, so that future disputes about respective shares of gas consumption should no longer arise. Separate valves on the pipeline at Zvomik would ensure that the supply to either party could be cut off at the request of the gas supplier or the transit companies in case of payment default. III. THE GAS SYSTEM A. SYSTEM CHARACTERISTICS 27. The gas system in Bosnia and Herzegovina consists of transmission and distribution systems. The transmission pipeline system imports gas from Russia. From Zvomik at the border between the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY) and BH the main line extends in a southwesterly direction to Sarajevo, entering the Federation at Kladanj. This line was constructed in 1979 and is 117 km long. An additional line going in a northwesterly direction goes from Sarajevo to Zenica. That line is approximately 65 km long and was constructed in 1982. Both transmission lines supply consumers at various take-off points along their length. Prior to the war, most of the gas was consumed by commercial and industrial customers in Sarajevo and industrial consumers in Zenica and Kakanj. Both the transmission pipeline from Zvornik to Sarajevo and the initial distribution system in Sarajevo were builtunder a World Bank loan (Loan 1264-YU; 1975). The transmission line to Zenica was financed by the Zenica Steel Works. 28. The main gas transmission pipeline was designed for a maximum volume of 1,260 million cubic meters (MCM) per year. Consumption peaked in 1990, at 610 MCM per year. In 1992, the flow to Zenica was shut off and the gas flow into Sarajevo was adequate to serve only small commercial and residential consumers. The consumed gas volume in 1992 was only 125 MCM.
 8 29. The distribution system in Sarajevo was built from 1979 to 1982. Before the war, the system supplied industry, district heating plants and about 15,000 individual households. Natural gas is distributed in the city of Sarajevo and its suburbs at three working pressure levels: 8 bar, 3 bar and 0.1 bar. The 8 bar steel network for the high pressure loop line has a length of 80 km, with a maximum working pressure of up to 14.5 bar. The regular network for the medium 3 bar pressure loop line has a length of about 15 km and is made of a combination of polyethylene (80%) and steel (20%) pipe. The maximum working pressure of this medium pressure network is 4 bar. The low pressure distribution network has a length of approximately 600 km and is made entirely of polyethylene pipes. The material which has been used for the networks corresponds to Western European standards. B. SYSTEM PROBLEMS 30. Transmission System. The high pressure transmission lines and facilities transporting the gas from the international border to the communities and industrial installations were not maintained during the war. Hence, the safety and reliability of the transmission system has deteriorated severely. A transmission line failure would stop the gas flow in the entire system. The materials and equipment to repair a failure, should it occur, are not available. Severe problems presently endangering the transmission system are: (i) possible bursting of the pipeline due to damage from shelling, sniper fire and excessive loading from armoured military vehicles; (ii) land movements, erosion and underminings at river and stream crossings; and (iii) external and internal corrosion. 31. Very little pipeline maintenance could be done during the war. Most of the maintenance records of the pipeline were destroyed or lost, so that very little baseline data exists. Virtually all equipment was lost. Spare parts must be made available for regular maintenance and repair. A procurement, warehousing and spare parts policy needs to be developed based on the equipment in the system. Pipe for line cut-outs and pipeline maintenance material needs to be procured and warehoused in a suitable environment. However, stores and shelters that used to protect mechanical equipment against weather impact suffered various degrees of damage during the war. These structures, tools, spare parts, workshops or warehouse equipment required for mechanical works need to be repaired. 32. Distribution System. During the war, natural gas was the main source of energy in Sarajevo, since oil, liquefied petroleum gas, electricity, coal and wood supplies quickly became scarce or exhausted. Electricity was often cut off and the district heating systems that used to supply densely populated parts of the city could operate only partly. To meet basic heating and cooking requirements, the Sarajevo gas distribution system was expanded to a large number of residences. Some of these connections were installed with the help of international humanitarian aid organizations according to industry standards. However, the vast majority of these connections were made by unskilled labor with salvaged materials. Pressure regulating and metering devices were not installed. Existing regulating and metering devices were often bypassed or removed because of the low pressures in the distribution lines. Building internal installations for district heating were cannibalized and converted into gas pipes. Hand-made burners and heaters were installed without safety shut-off devices. These improvised connections and appliances,
 9 combined with an absence of gas odor, led to frequent explosions which resulted in fatalities, injuries, and fires. However, gas odorization equipment was reinstalled in December 1995 and the number of explosions declined sharply since. 33. Current Situation. As of the end of 1995, gas consumption constituted about 70% of all energy consumption and it was the basic heating and cooking fuel for the city's remaining 300,000 inhabitants. Since the beginning of the war, the network expanded from 15,000 to about 89,000 household connections. Approximately 22,000 of these installations have been normalized to date, including exterior piping, meters and regulators. About 34,000 former district heating customers were returned to the district heating system as a result of successful implementation of the first phase of the Bank's Emergency District Heating Reconstruction Project. The total number of gas consumers was about 53,000 as of November, 1997. 34. The self-made heating and cooking devices used by many consumers are quickly deteriorating due to the inadequate materials and fabrication techniques used. Climatic exposure and working stress make the materials brittle and prone to leaking, causing gas-related incidents while the waste of gas through leaks continues. The handmade appliances are estimated to be up to 50% less efficient than commercial appliances. Effective demand side management measures require that this improvised equipmentbe replaced as soon as possible. IV. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 35. The first objective of the project is to restore a safe and reliable gas supply to BH, in particular to Sarajevo, as soon as possible, by repairing or reconstructing the gas transmission and distribution systems. This includes rehabilitation of the transmission line, distribution network and connections of large gas users, including Toplane, and reconnection of 34,000 flats to a functioning district heating system (they have already been transferred). The remaining 3,000 connections would be taken off the system2. The second objective is to enhance system and energy efficiency and reduce environmental pollution by converting self-made gas connections to industry standards. This will include installing new meters and regulators on 42,000 connections, repairing meters and regulators on the other connections and replacing home made heating and cooking devices of low-income families with 10,000 simple wall heaters and two plate cookers. Other objectives are to enhance cost recovery, strengthen the institutional capacity of Sarajevogas, and identify alternative sources of gas supply. The project would include the repair of transmission facilities within Republika Srpska. These consumers cannot be served economically by the natural gas system and would have to use alternative fuels for heating and cooking, such as LPG or electricity.
 10 B. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 36. Gas System Reconstruction To Date. Reconstruction prior to January 1996 consisted of efforts by humanitarian aid organizations, with labor being supplied by Sarajevogas and the citizens of the City. Relief projects were funded by several Middle Eastern countries, the UK, the Netherlands and the US. Implementation was coordinated primarily through a British engineering and construction company (AMEC) and Sarajevogas. These projects consisted of the rehabilitation of about 10,000 self made connections and the installation of approximately 200 km of network piping. In addition, substantial reconstruction of the city gate station of Hum was carried out as well as some work on the cathodic protection system for the steel lines in the city distribution network. Some heating and cooking devices were also supplied. Metering was not provided by the humanitarian aid organizations. 37. From January 1996-September 1997, significant additional reconstruction took place. The reconstruction activities and their costs are listed under cofinancing in Annex 1. In general, this aid consisted of the supply of materials -- European and Middle Eastern donors, plus US$5 million in IDA funds from the PSA. In addition, the various municipalities in the Sarajevo area financed some of the reconstruction, mostly through the supply of materials. Over 200 km of trenches for new network piping were dug by volunteer citizen labor. Some of the tools were supplied by Sarajevogas. The total dollar value of the investments cofinanced this way, including the value of citizen self-help, is estimated at US$11.9 million. Contributions by the EU, The Netherlands, the UK and others brings the total amount of cofinancing to US$22.1 million. 38. Project Description. The proposed project consists of the following major components: (i) engineering analysis of entire gas transmission and distribution systems; (ii) physical reconstruction of the gas system (except the Semizovac-Zenica branch of the transmission pipeline, which belongs to the Zenica Steel Works (para 42); (iii) technical assistance to Sarajevogas to implement the project and enhance its institutional capacity in management, technical and commercial aspects and finance; and (iv) a district heating component covering goods and works to refund the Project Start-up Advance (para. 65). Details of the project are described below. 1. Engineering Component 39. Project Engineering. An engineering contract would be given to an international consulting engineering firm to assist in the analysis, design and contracting for the reconstruction of both the transmission and the distribution system. Among the tasks would be to determine the extent of pipeline corrosion. Most of the engineering work would probably be done by Bosnian firns. This would produce economies in project implementation. Technical assistance to Sarajevogas would be provided to support the entity in project implementation and strengthen the operational capability of the entity. a) Transmission System 40. An engineering analysis would be performed to identify the risks associated with the current status of the transmission pipeline and to evaluate existing problems. This analysis would
 11 include the use of visual inspection and high technology sensing devices to identify and evaluate pipeline defects. A coating analysis, along with a survey of coating integrity, would be performed to determine areas where the coating needs to be repaired. A hydrostatic test would be conducted, if required, to ensure the strength of the pipeline and to reestablish the maximum allowable working pressure. C. ECONOMIC JUSTIFICATION 89. Comparison of Heating Options. During the war, coal and oil (and generally wood) were not available for space heating. Electricity supplies were sharply reduced and were only sporadically available for short periods of time. Hence space heating with electricity - widespread before the war - also was no longer an option. The gas-fired district heating system was partly damaged early in the war and could supply only one-third of its normal service area. The availability of natural gas, although at low pressure and in restricted quantities, led about 74,000 households and some commercial entities to make their own improvised connections to the gas network. These installations are very unsafe: since their introduction there have been 220 explosions related to gas use, resulting in 32 fatalities and more than 200 injuries. In addition, the installations last for only one to two years and use up to twice as much gas to produce the same useful heat as would be needed for proper installations. This improvised heat supply option was adopted under the severest of emergency conditions and obviously should be replaced as soon as
 24 possible. Some 34,000 customers have already been switched back to district heating. Under the proposed project, 38,000 irregular household connections would be converted to regular gas connections and the 15,000 pre-war household gas connections would be rehabilitated (the meter/regulator sets on these connections need to be repaired or replaced). All 53,000 gas consumers would be fully regularized by the end of 1998. The altemative option of supplying these customers with district heat would be very costly because of the distance from existing heat networks; these networks serve apartment buildings whereas the direct gas household consumers live in detached dwellings. Comparisons with other alternative space heating and cooking options confirmed that gas is less costly than electricity (using either ordinary space heaters or storage heaters that operate only during off-peak hours) or a combination of fuel oil for space heating and liquified petroleum gas (LPG) for cooking (Annex 5). 90. Economic Rate of Return Calculation. An economic rate of return is normally not calculated for emergency reconstruction projects since the need for those investments is usually evident and the data needed for the calculation are often deficient. However, an estimate was made for the proposed project since some useful data on benefits have become available as a result of investments already made for the project, especially on meters and a computerized billing system. 91. In the absence of the project most consumers are assumed to use their existing (or improved) irregular connections. This has occurred up to now, and new inhabitants of houses abandoned at the end of the war have made new irregular connections. The benefits of the project include: (i) avoided costs of new or replaced irregular connections; (ii) avoided gas transmission and distribution losses; (iii) avoided costs from gas explosions; (iv) avoided uneconomic consumption of gas due to the absence of meters and regulators; and (v) the avoided cost of substitute energy that would be needed if the irregular connection system had to be shut down for safety reasons because of the danger posed by ever greater gas leaks over time. 92. The above benefits were estimated as follows: (i) The avoided connection cost benefit assumes that, in the absence of the project, 38,000 improvised connections would be replaced every two years at a cost per connection of DM150 (DM 30 for a steel saddle, DM 20 for steel pipe and DM 100 for indoor installation). (ii) The avoided transmission and distribution loss estimate assumes that, in the absence of the project, losses, mostly in the irregular distribution network, would rise from about 4% of gas consumption by households in 1997 to 10% in 2000, after which distribution to households would be shut off because of the danger of explosions.3 The lost gas is valued at the delivered import gas cost of $118/thousand ni3 plus operating cost of $3/thousand m3. 3 Individual consumers would not repair the improvised leaking network on their own unless they know that it is the sections they had built which are leaking.
 25 (iii) The avoided accident cost estimate assumes, in the absence of the project, 28 explosions per year (equal to the rate since an odorant was added to the gas) and a cost of DM125,000 to replace a destroyed house and contents. No account is taken of the costs attributable to deaths or injuries. While most recent explosions have been in empty dwellings, they can occur in dwellings where elderly persons live who cannot smell leaking gas or where children too young to deal with a gas leak are left alone. (iv) The avoided uneconomic gas consumption was estimated on the basis of data for the months of December 1996 to March 1997, during which Sarajevogas's new computerized billing system was in effect. Average consumption by unmetered households (mostly irregular) during this period was 43% higher than consumption by metered (regularized) households. The extra consumption was due to the absence of regulators (which reduce gas pressure from 100 millibars to 25-35 millibars) and billing based on unmetered consumption (as a result, the unmetered consumer has no incentive to limit consumption). The value of this extra consumption to an individual consumer would be very small. It was assumed to be one-quarter of the retail household gas price of DM 37/m3 for each extra m3 consumed. The cost of the extra consumption was valued at the import price of US$118/thousand m3 plus US$3/thousand m3 for operating costs. The net extra cost is US$9.34/m3 of extra consumption. (v) The avoided cost of a fuel substitute was estimated as the difference between the cost of heating and cooking by gas (assuming regularized connections) and the cost of heating with fuel oil and cooking with liquified petroleum gas (Annex 5). The oil alternative was selected rather than the more widely used electricity option, since its cost was estimated to be lower. 93. For purposes of the rate of return calculation, the costs were taken as the total project cost ($43.5 million) less the transmission investment in RS (US$1.5 million) and the cost of studies of sector restructuring and alternative gas supply sources (US$1.85 million). The RS transmission component was excluded since it is already taken into account in the fee for gas transit through RS. The studies were excluded because of the difficulty of quantifying their benefits, even though they could be large. 94. The cost and benefit estimates exclude taxes. The existing exchange rate of US$1.00 = DM1.75 was considered to be equal to the shadow rate of foreign exchange because of the use of the DM as the main domestic currency in the Federation. Actual wage rates were assumed in the absence of a reliable estimate of a shadow wage rate. However, a sensitivity calculation is shown below in which the voluntary labor of gas consumers in helping construct regularized connections is valued at zero rather than US$9.1 million. 95. The internal economic rate of return was estimated to be 30%, which is more than satisfactory (the calculation is in Annex 6). Sensitivity tests were carried out with respect to changes in key parameters in order to determine the switching values. The changes needed to reduce the rate of return to the assumed opportunity cost of capital of 12% would be: (i) a 300% increase in the 1998 investment cost; or (ii) a 110% increase in the delivered natural gas import
 26 price; or (iii) a 40% reduction in heating oil and LPG prices; or (iv) a 60% reduction in household gas consumption. Postponing the assumed date of shutdown of the improvised gas system would reduce the rate of return, but even a postponement beyond the year 2011 would not bring the rate down to 12%. If voluntary labor in constructing regular distribution network and installing improvised gas connections is valued at zero, the rate of return would rise to 42%. 96. Sensitivity tests were also carried out to evaluate whether the risk of future interruption in gas supplies would offset the advantage of natural gas over electricity. While the conclusion of satisfactory contracts for the import of natural gas should assure a continuous supply to Sarajevo from now on, another interruption due to political events in RS cannot be entirely ruled out. Many households have already taken precautions against further interruptions by buying electric heaters and/or maintaining the possibility of using wood as fuel. In these circumstances, it is justifiable to add the cost of the appliances for using substitute energy to the cost of the natural gas option. From Annex 5, it can be seen that by including in the gas option the cost of four electric storage heaters per household for all 53,000 gas-connected households (which would provide the same amount of heat) the gas option would still have a lower present value of costs than the option of using electricity with storage heaters. The electricity option (with storage heaters) would, however, become less costly than the gas option if gas would not be available for more than the next two years. The prospects of such an outcome are slim, first since households would spend much less than assumed here on electric space heaters for back-up use, and, second, since a two-year interruption in gas supplies is highly unlikely. D. RISKS 97. There are no significant risks associated with this project, other than a renewed outbreak of hostilities or interruption of the gas supply by RS for political reasons. Consumers' ability to pay, while still low, has been increasing steadily. Any operating deficits would be funded by the Sarajevo Canton budget, which is quite robust, or services would have to be cut back. However, the financial risk of Sarajevogas having inadequate cash flow is addressed by the project's emphasis on speedy reintroduction of billing and collection and by agreeing on specific minimum targets for collections on an annual basis. A tariff study would be implemented and, over the longer term, tariffs ought to reflect costs in order to ensure adequate enterprise cash flow to maintain and expand the system. Project cost overruns are possible, despite the inclusion of a 10% physical contingency on the uncommitted portion of the project, if the damage in certain areas turns out to be more severe than expected. Implementation delays might occur because of unexpected technical complications and because of a possible multiplicity of procurement procedures, depending on the number of donors and international financial institutions involved. The latter risk is manageable, because qualified experts will assist Sarajevogas in procurement and project implementation. The risk of the project's financing plan remaining incomplete (financing gap) has been mitigated by the design of the project, with the higher priority investments being carried out first. Furthermore, the remaining financing gap is quite small and expected to be closed soon. The most serious risk, future interruptions of the gas supply, has been mitigated by the conclusion of satisfactory long-term agreements with Gazexport and the transit companies in Hungary, FRY and Republika Srpska, respectively.

doc.repnme: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency Natural Gas System Reconstruction Project
doc.abstracts: The Emergency Natural Gas System Reconstruction Project has several objectives: a) to restore a safe and reliable gas supply to Bosnia-Herzegovina, and in particular to Sarajevo, as soon as possible by repairing or reconstructing the gas transmission and distribution systems; b) to enhance safety and energy efficiency and reduce environmental pollution by converting self-made gas connections to industry standards; and c) to enhance cost recovery, strengthen the institutional capacity of Sarajevogas, identify alternative sources of gas supply, and repair the transmission facilities within Republika Sprska. The project consists of the following main components: 1) engineering analysis of the gas transmission and distribution systems; 2) physical reconstruction of the gas system; 3) technical assistance to Sarajevogas to implement the project and enhance institutional capacity in management, technical, and commercial/financial aspects; and 4) a district heating component covering goods and works to offset the Project Start-up Advance, which is to be used for project preparation and start-up activities.
